Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Site Toolkit for Augmented Reality Exhibits: Bringing Easy-To-Use Augmented Reality to Open Air Museum Sites
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project provides tools and methods for open air cultural heritage and environmental education sites to deploy augmented reality (AR) based exhibits. AR is an established technology that can bring educational material to life. However, the museum industry has been unable to tap into its full potential because AR installations are technically challenging to implement, requiring the purchase of expensive hardware and use of highly skilled technical staff to create and deploy the content. This project provides a software tool suite designed to enable cultural heritage and environmental education sites to more quickly, easily, and cost-effectively create and deploy AR exhibits than is currently possible. AR exhibits developed using these tools will enable institutions to deploy engaging virtual exhibits with dynamic geospatially-based content at locations in which deploying traditional interpretive content is extremely difficult. This in turn will provide NSF funded research projects with the ability to disseminate their latest research results to the public in a timely and easily deployable fashion. Making AR use practical will lead to more engaging exhibits, generating greater visitor enthusiasm and learning which will, in turn, produce more visitors, larger donations, and create jobs within the Museum industry focused on developing AR exhibits.

This project will produce content creation and viewing software and a business model designed to provide cost effective creation, deployment, and maintenance of Augmented Reality (AR) exhibits. The toolkit will be comprised of four technological components: a mobile viewer application running on iOS and Android, a content delivery server, a web based exhibit intelligence tool designed to monitor the use of the exhibit, and a web based content creation system with automated functions for authoring and checking material. The business model is designed to make AR exhibits revenue neutral or profit generating by sharing the income generated from the viewer application sales. Together these elements create a new approach to implementing augmented reality in open air museums that is designed to overcome the major issues limiting the practical use of AR by these institutions. Phase I of this project will concentrate on the development of the mobile viewer application and the exhibit intelligence tool. A prototype exhibit will also be developed for testing in Phase II. The experience gained from creating the content for this exhibit will guide the requirements and interface of the content creation software to be developed in Phase II.

POR.DRECONTENT:
STARE Summary Outcomes Report 

Prepared by:  CHI Systems, Inc.  

Augmented Reality (AR) promises an exciting new platform for educational, social-media, and entertainment-focused story-telling and society is only beginning to uncover the true potential that if offers. The STARE project enabled CHI Systems, Inc. to engage historical and cultural heritage sites and validate the concept that AR, even in these early stages of adoption and maturation, is an excellent match to enable historical sites to develop interactive exhibits that can help site interpreters tell their stories.  The importance of making AR content creation through STARE accessible was a prevalent theme during Phase I discussions with site partners.  STARE technology has the potential to empower site interpreters to develop augmented reality exhibits and deploy them for viewing without requiring extensive engineering expertise. 

In speaking to potential customer sites we learned that the curation of exhibits is all about story-telling.  Sites want to tell a story around a set of locations, people, objects, artifacts, and events in a way that connects in a personal way with the visitor.  Augmented reality presents an opportunity to mix various forms of media – computer images/animations, video, audio – and tie those elements to artifacts, locations, and objects in order to tell an interactive story that can 'bring to life' the human element of an exhibit in a way that few media can.  This reinforces CHI Systems’ findings that a key factor in driving the successful adoption, use, and sustainment of similar tools is the integration of task-based content development tools with a well-designed and intuitive user interface paired with seamless and cost-effective deployment tools.  CHI Systems’ innovation lies in the fact that we couple easy-to-use content authoring/development tools with scalable infrastructure for deployment of that content. 

During Phase I, CHI Systems established and achieved two high level outcome goals:

  • Validating the STARE business model by conducting and analyzing customer discovery interviews to refine and improve the business approach.   We also utilized the relationships developed in the customer discovery process to establish partnerships with multiple historic/cultural heritage sites to gain access to industry experts that could serve as collaborators in current and future development.  These collaborations allowed us to develop realistic use cases, content, design input and product testing for Phase I (and subsequent Phase II) STARE development.  They also allowed us to begin cultivating opportunities for commercial sales to and in collaboration with these partners in Phase III.
  • Establishing technical proof-of-concept through a series of design mockups, small-scale technology prototypes, and by conducting a technology evaluation of existing Augmented Reality (AR) tools in order to inform the STARE design.  We developed a design concept for a systematic approach to creating STARE-based Augmented Reality (AR) exhibits that would be consistent with established historic interpretation and storytelling approaches standards while offering substantial new benefits to STARE customers and their customers (the park/museum/site visitors).  We created the STARE concept in collaboration with site partners (developed through the customer-discovery process) to ensure that the STARE design represents the roles of various stakeholders and purchase influencers in the exhibit curation process, and that it enabled digital exhibits to be rapidly and cost-effectively be developed through a well-designed software platform and user-centered interface.

There are five significant ways in which STARE provides societal benefits: 1) increasing the level of visitor engagement and learning at cultural tourism sites, 2) allowing sites to quickly add high quality AR exhibit content in reaction to current events and public discourse, 3) allowing US based research institutions to quickly deploy interpretive exhibits on Federally funded research sites located in foreign countries and remote locations, 4) creating jobs in the tourism industry as a result of increased visitors drawn to experience the newly created and engaging exhibits, and 5) enabling digital media companies that manually develop mixed-media interactive applications to  quickly develop STARE exhibits.  This would create an industry for AR media specialists that would utilize STARE to more efficiently develop AR exhibits in the same way Adobe Flash did for that same industry in the early days of digital media development, which was a growth-engine for over two decades.  In addition, we foresee direct job creation in the museum industry for jobs supporting STARE content planning and creation activities.
